vocabulary.name: Professional Vocabulary
vocabulary.desc: Collocations, phrasal verbs, precise word choice

register.name: Professional Register
register.desc: Formal vs casual, email tone, audience awareness

vocabulary.title: Professional Vocabulary
vocabulary.problem: You're using words that don't naturally go together. Native speakers say 'reach a decision' not 'make a decision' in formal contexts. These errors immediately mark you as non-native.
vocabulary.tip: Start a collocation notebook. When you learn a new business verb, write down 3-4 words it partners with. 'Raise' goes with: concerns, questions, issues, points. Review daily.

diplomatic.title: Diplomatic Language
diplomatic.problem: Your communication is too direct. Saying 'This won't work' damages relationships. You need softening: 'I have some concerns we might want to explore.'
diplomatic.tip: Learn the hedging hierarchy: might â†’ could â†’ may â†’ would â†’ appears to â†’ suggests. Practice transforming direct statements into diplomatic ones daily.

register.title: Professional Register
register.problem: You're misjudging formality levels. Writing 'Hey!' to executives or 'Dear Sir' to colleagues undermines credibility. Register awareness is a key marker of competence.
register.tip: Create a register scale for each situation. New client = formal. Daily colleague = friendly professional. Learn the markers: 'I am writing to...' (formal) vs 'Just wanted to...' (casual).

pragmatic.title: Workplace Communication
pragmatic.problem: You know WHAT to say but not HOW to say it professionally. Requests need softening. Disagreements need face-saving. This is the difference between competent and professional.
pragmatic.tip: Learn request formulas by directness level. Very indirect: 'I was wondering if perhaps...' Indirect: 'Would you be able to...' Direct: 'Could you...' Use more indirect forms for bigger requests.

L1.q: Complete: The board will _____ a final decision next week.
L1.sentence: The board will _____ a final decision next week.
L1.explain: 'Reach a decision' is the formal business collocation. It implies deliberation and consensus. 'Make a decision' is acceptable but less sophisticated in boardroom contexts.

L1.q: Complete: We need to _____ concerns about the timeline.
L1.sentence: We need to _____ concerns about the timeline.
L1.explain: 'Address concerns' is the business collocation. You don't 'say' or 'speak' concerns. This is a common error that marks non-native speakers.

L1.q: Which shows appropriate hedging for early data?
options: The data proves our approach is working.
Early data suggests our approach may be having a positive effect.
Our approach is definitely successful based on the data.
The numbers confirm everything we expected.
L1.explain: 'Suggests' and 'may be' hedge appropriately for preliminary findings. Overclaiming ('proves', 'definitely', 'confirms') damages your credibility when data is still early.

L1.scenario: Email to a potential client you've never met.
options: Hey there! Thanks for reaching out!
Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing with reference to your inquiry dated...
Thank you for your interest in our services. I'd be happy to provide more information.
Hi! Got your message. Here's what you need to know.
L1.explain: Option C balances professionalism with warmth. Option B is overly formal and dated. Options A and D are too casual for a new client relationship.

L1.scenario: You need to ask your manager for time off next week.
L1.q: Which opening is most professionally appropriate?
options: Hi, do you have a moment? I wanted to check something with you.
L1.explain: Professional requests require 'pre-expansion' - checking availability before the request. 'Do you have a moment?' signals a request is coming and respects their time.

L1.q: Complete: We need to _____ this issue at the next meeting.
L1.sentence: We need to _____ this issue at the next meeting.
L1.explain: 'Bring up' means to raise or mention a topic. 'Bring in' = involve someone. 'Bring out' = reveal. 'Bring on' = cause. Critical distinction.

L1.q: Complete: The proposal has merit. _____, the budget remains problematic.
L1.sentence: The proposal has merit. _____, the budget remains problematic.
L1.explain: 'That said' elegantly introduces a counterpoint while acknowledging the positive. 'Therefore' and 'Consequently' indicate result, not contrast.

L1.statement: The implementation faced initial resistance but ultimately succeeded.
options: The implementation failed due to resistance.
There were early obstacles, but the project achieved its goals.
L1.explain: 'Initial resistance BUT ultimately succeeded' means early problems followed by success. Precision in comprehension is critical.

L1.q: Complete: The CEO _____ the importance of meeting the deadline.
L1.sentence: The CEO _____ the importance of meeting the deadline.
L1.explain: 'Stress the importance' is the collocation. You can't 'say/tell/speak the importance.' This is a common B1-B2 error.

L1.scenario: Your colleague sent you a document to review. You found some issues.
L1.q: Which email response is most appropriate?
options: Your document has problems. Please fix them.
Thanks for sending this over. I've noted a few areas where we might want to add some clarification - happy to discuss.
I reviewed your document. It's not good enough.
Hey, doc needs work. Let's chat.
L1.explain: Professional feedback: acknowledge receipt, soften criticism ('a few areas', 'might want'), offer collaboration. Never attack the work directly.

L1.scenario: A client asks if you can deliver by Friday. You can't.
options: Friday is tight for us. Would Monday work, or should we discuss prioritizing specific deliverables for Friday?
L1.explain: Never just say no. Acknowledge, explain constraint briefly, offer alternatives. Give them choices rather than rejection.

L1.scenario: Your boss emails you at 11pm asking for an update. You're about to sleep.
options: Never - it's inappropriate to email so late
First thing tomorrow morning with a brief update
In a week when you have complete information
L1.explain: Late emails don't require late responses. Responding next morning shows you saw it and are responsive. Immediate response sets bad precedent; waiting too long is dismissive.

L1.q: Complete: We need to _____ a meeting to discuss the quarterly results.
L1.sentence: We need to _____ a meeting to discuss the quarterly results.
L1.explain: 'Set up a meeting' or 'arrange a meeting' are the collocations. 'Make a meeting' and 'do a meeting' are common non-native errors.

L1.scenario: You're writing a LinkedIn post about your company's achievement.
options: OMG we just crushed it!!! ðŸ”¥ðŸ”¥ðŸ”¥
I'm pleased to share that our team has achieved a significant milestone in Q4.
We did something. It was good.
L1.explain: LinkedIn is professional social media. Enthusiastic but measured tone. No excessive emojis or caps. Option B shows pride without being unprofessional.

L2.scenario: You need to ask a senior colleague to review your report by tomorrow. They're extremely busy.
options: I need you to review my report by tomorrow.
Could you review my report? I need it by tomorrow.
I know you're busy, and I wouldn't ask if it weren't urgent. Would you possibly have time to glance at my report before tomorrow's meeting?
Review my report please. Tomorrow deadline.
L2.explain: Effective requests for busy senior people need: acknowledgment of their time, justification, hedging ('possibly', 'glance'), and face-saving.

L2.q: Which is the most diplomatically effective alternative?
options: I think your analysis is wrong.
I wonder if we might want to revisit some of the assumptions underlying this analysis.
You made mistakes in your analysis.
L2.explain: Option C uses triple hedging: 'wonder if' (uncertainty), 'might want' (suggestion), 'revisit assumptions' (process focus). This protects the relationship.

L2.email:
Hi Team,

Just wanted to flag that the client's super unhappy about the delay. We gotta fix this ASAP or we're toast.

Cheers
L2.q: This email would be appropriate for:
options: A message to close teammates in a startup
A formal status update to senior management
A message to be forwarded to the board
L2.explain: This register (casual, slang, contractions) is only appropriate for very informal internal communication with peers. Never for management or clients.

L2.q: Complete: The merger will _____ significant changes across all departments.
L2.sentence: The merger will _____ significant changes across all departments.
L2.explain: 'Bring about changes' is the formal business collocation for causing change. More sophisticated than 'make changes'.

L2.scenario: A client proposes a timeline that's impossible to meet.
L2.q: Which response maintains the relationship while being honest?
options: I appreciate the ambition of that timeline. To deliver the quality you deserve, we'd need to adjust either scope or delivery date. Which would you prefer to explore?
No way. That timeline is unrealistic.
L2.explain: Effective pushback: validate ('appreciate'), explain constraint ('quality you deserve'), offer alternatives, give them choice. Consultative, not confrontational.

L2.statement: While quarterly revenue increased, year-over-year growth decelerated.
options: Revenue grew, but at a slower rate than the previous year.
The company made less money than last quarter.
L2.explain: 'Increased' = revenue went up. 'Decelerated' = the RATE of growth slowed. Understanding that growth can slow while still being positive is critical.

L2.q: Complete: The strategy is sound in theory. _____, execution will require resources we don't have.
L2.sentence: The strategy is sound in theory. _____, execution will require resources we don't have.
L2.explain: 'In practice, however' creates the theory/practice contrast elegantly. 'Therefore' would indicate the second point follows from the first (wrong logic).

L2.q: Complete: We need to _____ the details before signing.
L2.sentence: We need to _____ the details before signing.
L2.explain: 'Iron out' means to resolve problems or finalize details. Essential business phrasal verb.

L2.scenario: You're in a meeting and someone takes credit for your idea.
options: I'm glad that idea is gaining traction. To build on the point I raised earlier, I think we could also...
L2.explain: Reclaim subtly by referencing 'the point I raised earlier' while adding value. Direct accusation creates conflict; subtle assertion maintains professionalism.

L2.scenario: Writing a follow-up email after a job interview.
options: I look forward to hearing from you and would welcome the opportunity to discuss how I can contribute to your team.
L2.explain: Post-interview follow-up requires formal register. Express enthusiasm professionally, reiterate value, avoid pressure language ('ASAP', 'waiting').

L2.scenario: You notice a colleague is struggling with their workload.
L2.q: Which offer of help is most effective?
options: You look stressed. Do you need help?
I noticed you have the Henderson project and the quarterly review both due this week. I've got some bandwidth - would it help if I took the data compilation piece off your plate?
L2.explain: Effective offers: be specific (named projects), show you understand their situation, offer concrete help ('data compilation piece'), give them the choice.

L2.q: Complete: We need to _____ our efforts on the core product.
L2.sentence: We need to _____ our efforts on the core product.
L2.explain: 'Focus efforts on' and 'concentrate efforts on' are both correct. 'Focus' is more commonly used in business contexts. 'Put efforts' and 'make efforts' don't collocate with 'on'.

L2.scenario: Your manager gives you feedback you disagree with.
options: I appreciate the feedback. Could you help me understand what specifically led to that impression? I want to make sure I'm addressing the right issue.
L2.explain: When receiving feedback you question: thank them, ask for specifics, frame as wanting to improve. This opens dialogue without confrontation.

L2.scenario: Introducing yourself at a networking event to someone senior.
options: Hi! I'm Alex. I work in marketing. What do you do?

Hello, I'm Alexandra Chen. I lead digital marketing for Techcorp. I was particularly interested in your keynote on market trends - the point about emerging markets resonated with our current strategy.
I'm Alex from marketing. Nice to meet you.
L2.explain: Senior networking: full name, clear role, reference something specific to them, create a hook for conversation. Generic intros waste the opportunity.

L3.scenario: Presenting research with significant limitations to executives.
L3.q: Which demonstrates proper hedging for high-stakes communication?
options: Our research proves the market is ready.
The research confirms our hypothesis completely.
Preliminary findings appear to suggest potential market readiness, though further validation would be prudent before committing significant resources.
The market is definitely ready based on our research.
L3.explain: Layers of hedging: 'preliminary', 'appear to suggest', 'potential', 'would be prudent', 'before committing'. This protects credibility with executives.

L3.scenario: You strongly disagree with your CEO's proposed strategy in a meeting with other executives present.
L3.q: Which response is most strategically effective?
options: I can see the strategic logic. I'm wondering whether we've fully stress-tested this against scenarios where [specific concern]. Could we explore that dimension?
With respect, I think you're wrong about this.
L3.explain: Disagreeing with a CEO publicly: validation first ('I see the logic'), frame as inquiry not opposition ('wondering whether'), focus on process, invite exploration.

L3.scenario: Writing a persuasive email to the board requesting budget.
options: I really think we should do this. Trust me, it'll work.
Given the market analysis and projected 18-month ROI of 340%, this initiative merits consideration for Q2 implementation, contingent on the conditions outlined in Appendix B.
This is definitely the right move. We need to act now.
I want to request budget for my new idea. Please approve it.
L3.explain: Board communication requires: evidence-based framing, specific data, hedged recommendation ('merits consideration'), conditions ('contingent on'), documentation reference.

L3.statement: The ostensible cost savings were offset by unanticipated integration complexities.
options: The project saved money as expected.
The apparent savings didn't materialize because integration was harder than expected.
There were no cost savings or integration issues.
L3.explain: 'Ostensible' = apparent/seeming (not real). 'Offset' = cancelled out. 'Unanticipated' = unexpected. Parsing complex business language is essential.

L3.q: Complete: The board voted to _____ with the acquisition despite concerns.
L3.sentence: The board voted to _____ with the acquisition despite concerns.
L3.explain: 'Proceed with' is the most formal and precise collocation for official decisions. 'Go ahead with' is slightly less formal. 'Continue' implies something already started.

L3.scenario: Declining an important request from a senior partner without damaging the relationship.
options: I can't do that right now.

I'd genuinely like to support this - it's exactly the kind of initiative I value. Given my current commitments, I couldn't give it the attention it deserves. Could we revisit next quarter, or might [colleague] be able to step in?
L3.explain: Strategic decline: genuine validation, specific constraint, focus on quality ('attention it deserves'), future possibility, and alternative suggestion.

L3.q: Complete: The proposal addresses most concerns. _____, the timeline warrants further scrutiny.
L3.sentence: The proposal addresses most concerns. _____, the timeline warrants further scrutiny.
L3.explain: 'Notwithstanding this' (despite this positive) elegantly introduces a reservation. More sophisticated than 'however'.

L3.scenario: You've found a significant error in a senior colleague's analysis.
options: There's an error in your analysis.
I might be missing something, but I'm getting different figures when I run the numbers. Could we walk through the methodology together?
L3.explain: Self-deprecation hedge ('might be missing something'), focus on data not person ('getting different figures'), collaborative framing ('walk through together').

L3.scenario: Responding to a negative online review of your company.
options: Thank you for taking the time to share your feedback. We're sorry your experience didn't meet expectations. We'd welcome the opportunity to make this right - please contact us directly at [email].
This review is unfair and inaccurate.
L3.explain: Public response to criticism: thank them, acknowledge without admitting fault ('didn't meet expectations'), offer resolution privately. Never argue publicly.

L3.scenario: A colleague publicly challenges your expertise in a meeting.
L3.q: Which response maintains credibility without escalating?
options: I know what I'm talking about.
That's an interesting perspective. My recommendation is based on [specific evidence/experience]. I'd be happy to share the data afterward if that would be helpful.
I've been doing this longer than you.
L3.explain: Acknowledge their input ('interesting perspective'), cite your basis ('specific evidence'), offer proof without fighting. Maintain composure and authority.

L3.q: Complete: The initiative failed to gain _____ among key stakeholders.
L3.sentence: The initiative failed to gain _____ among key stakeholders.
L3.explain: 'Gain traction' is the business idiom for gaining support/progress. 'Gain momentum' could work but 'traction' is more precise for stakeholder buy-in.

L3.scenario: You need to deliver bad news about a project delay to a demanding client.
L3.q: How should you structure the communication?
options: Start with the delay, then explain reasons.
Apologize extensively, then give the delay.
Lead with what you're doing to fix it, acknowledge the impact, explain briefly, then reconfirm your commitment.
Blame the circumstances beyond your control.
L3.explain: Bad news structure: solution first (shows you're handling it), acknowledge impact (shows empathy), brief explanation (not excuses), commitment (rebuilds trust).

L3.scenario: You're asked to present at a conference with very short notice.
options: I'm honored to be considered. Given the timeline, I could deliver a strong presentation on [Topic A] where I have existing material, or a more overview-level session on [Topic B]. Which would be more valuable for your audience?
L3.explain: Turn constraints into options. Express appreciation, acknowledge reality, offer what you CAN do well, let them choose. Professional flexibility.

L3.q: Complete: We need to _____ our competitive position in the market.
L3.sentence: We need to _____ our competitive position in the market.
L3.explain: 'Consolidate a position' means to strengthen and secure it. This is formal business language for protecting market share. 'Make/do/create a position' don't collocate.

L4.scenario: In a negotiation, the other party has made an offer significantly below your acceptable range. You need to reject it without killing the deal.
L4.q: Which response is most strategically sophisticated?
options: That's too low. We need more.

I appreciate you putting a number on the table - that helps move us forward. We're some distance apart, which tells me we might be valuing different aspects of this deal. Could you help me understand what's driving that figure?
L4.explain: Advanced negotiation: acknowledge their move positively, name the gap neutrally, reframe as different perspectives (not wrong/right), invite explanation.

L4.scenario: Writing to the audit committee about a compliance concern you've identified.
options: In reviewing our Q3 processes, I've identified what may constitute a potential deviation from regulatory requirements. While preliminary analysis suggests exposure may be limited, I would recommend independent verification before reaching a definitive assessment.
There might be a small issue with compliance.
L4.explain: Risk communication to audit: factual framing, multiple hedges ('may constitute', 'potential', 'suggests', 'may be'), specificity, action recommendation, caveat.

L4.statement: The committee's qualified endorsement of the proposal, while not constituting formal approval, nonetheless signals directional alignment with the strategic intent.
options: The committee fully approved the proposal.
The committee expressed conditional support - not formal approval, but agreement with the overall direction.
L4.explain: 'Qualified endorsement' = conditional support. 'Not constituting formal approval' = not official yes. 'Directional alignment' = agree with overall direction.

L4.scenario: Responding to a journalist's inquiry about a sensitive internal matter.
L4.q: Which response is most professionally appropriate?
options: Thank you for reaching out. While we don't comment on internal processes, we remain committed to [relevant value] and would be happy to discuss our public-facing initiatives in this area.
L4.explain: Media response: acknowledge the inquiry, state the boundary professionally, pivot to positive messaging, offer an alternative. Standard PR training.

L4.scenario: You're facilitating a meeting where two senior executives are in open conflict.
options: You both need to calm down.
I'm hearing two valid perspectives here, and I think we're actually closer than it might feel. Could we take a step back and identify what we agree on before we tackle where we diverge?
You're both right, let's just compromise.
L4.explain: Conflict facilitation: validate both ('two valid perspectives'), reframe ('closer than it might feel'), process suggestion ('step back'), sequence strategically.

L4.q: Complete: The findings _____ serious questions about the current approach.
L4.sentence: The findings _____ serious questions about the current approach.
L4.explain: 'Raise questions' is the formal collocation. 'Put questions' is incorrect. 'Give' doesn't collocate. Precise formal collocations matter.

L4.scenario: Presenting a recommendation you're confident about to skeptical stakeholders.
L4.q: Which balances confidence with appropriate hedging?
options: This is definitely the right approach.
Based on the evidence gathered, I believe this approach offers the strongest risk-adjusted path forward. I'd welcome challenge on any of the underlying assumptions.
I guess we could try this.
L4.explain: Confident hedging: evidence-based ('based on evidence'), owned opinion ('I believe'), qualified claim ('risk-adjusted'), invites scrutiny ('welcome challenge').

L4.q: Complete: The analysis is methodologically sound. _____, its practical applicability remains to be demonstrated.
L4.sentence: The analysis is methodologically sound. _____, its practical applicability remains to be demonstrated.
L4.explain: 'Be that as it may' is a sophisticated concessive connector meaning 'despite that being true.' More advanced than 'however'.

L4.scenario: Your team member has made a significant error that affected a client. You need to address it.
L4.q: Which approach is most effective for long-term performance?
options: You really messed this up. Don't let it happen again.
Let's talk through what happened with the Johnson account. I want to understand the sequence of events so we can figure out how to prevent this in future. What was your thinking at each step?
I'm disappointed. This was a big mistake.
We need to discuss your error.
L4.explain: Effective feedback: specific reference, curiosity framing ('understand', 'thinking'), future focus ('prevent'), no blame language. Builds learning, not defensiveness.

L4.scenario: Announcing a difficult organizational change (layoffs) to remaining staff.
L4.q: Which communication approach is most appropriate?
options: Some people had to go. It was a business decision.
We had to make some tough calls today. I know this affects all of us.

Following a comprehensive review of our organizational structure aligned with strategic imperatives, we have implemented workforce adjustments affecting approximately 12% of positions. We remain committed to supporting affected colleagues through this transition.
Don't worry, your jobs are safe. Let's move on.
L4.explain: Difficult announcements require: formal register, factual framing ('comprehensive review'), precise numbers, acknowledgment, support commitment. Option B is too casual for this gravity.

L4.statement: The synergies predicated upon the merger have yet to materialize in any substantive capacity.
options: The merger created significant cost savings.
The expected benefits from the merger haven't actually happened.
The merger was a complete success.
The synergies are performing above expectations.
L4.explain: 'Predicated upon' = based on/expected from. 'Yet to materialize' = haven't happened. 'Substantive capacity' = in any real way. Translation: expected merger benefits haven't come.

L4.scenario: A vendor is significantly late on a delivery that's impacting your project. You need to escalate without destroying the relationship.
options: This is completely unacceptable. We're considering other vendors.
We need to talk about the delivery delays.

I want to maintain our strong partnership, which is why I'm raising this directly. The current timeline puts us in a difficult position with our own stakeholders. Can we get on a call today to discuss recovery options and what support you might need from us?
L4.explain: Effective escalation: affirm relationship, explain impact ('difficult position'), request immediate action, offer collaboration ('support you might need'). Pressure with partnership.

L4.scenario: Your company has made a public error. You're drafting a statement.
options: We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused.
We take full responsibility for [specific issue]. This fell short of our standards and your expectations. Here's what we're doing to make it right: [actions]. We're committed to regaining your trust.
Mistakes happen. We're working on it.
We're sorry you feel that way.
L4.explain: Crisis response: specific acknowledgment (not vague), take responsibility, acknowledge standards, concrete actions, commitment. Generic 'sorry for any inconvenience' is seen as dismissive.

L4.q: Complete: The acquisition is _____ on regulatory approval.
L4.sentence: The acquisition is _____ on regulatory approval.
L4.explain: 'Contingent on' is the formal legal/business term meaning conditional upon. 'Dependent on' is acceptable but less precise. 'Relying on' and 'waiting on' are informal.

L4.scenario: In a salary negotiation, the employer says 'That's our final offer.'
L4.q: Which response keeps the door open?
options: I understand budget constraints. Before I make my decision, could we explore whether there's flexibility in other areas - perhaps signing bonus, equity, or additional PTO?
L4.explain: When they say 'final': acknowledge constraint, don't challenge directly, expand the pie by exploring other forms of compensation. Keep collaborative tone.

L4.scenario: You're writing a recommendation letter for a colleague.
options: She's really good at her job.

I have known Ms. Chen for three years in my capacity as her direct supervisor. She consistently demonstrated exceptional analytical capabilities and delivered results that exceeded expectations by an average of 23% against targets.
She's one of the best people I've worked with.
L4.explain: Recommendation letters require: formal relationship establishment, specific competencies, quantified achievements. Vague praise ('really good', 'one of the best') carries little weight.
